newsitem.title: UK: World insurance premiums over $2,000 bln - report.
newsitem.headline: World insurance premiums over $2,000 bln - report.

text.p: World insurance premiums have broken through the $2,000 billion mark for the first time, but while Asia is booming, growth in Europe and America has fallen off, according to reinsurers Swiss Re.
In its latest Sigma research report, Swiss Re said insurance premium volume in 1995 was $2,143.4 billion, an increase of 3.7 per cent on the previous year.
"This indicated growth which, like the previous year, was below the long term average of 4.6 per cent", the report said.
In a sluggish year, non life insurance achieved a turnover of $906.8 billion, up 2.2 per cent, mostly from Europe and the U.S.
Life insurance counted for $1,236.6 billion, up 5.3 per cent, reaching highs in Japan and South Korea, South Africa and Switzerland.
In the U.S., falling prices in non-life insurance led to weak growth, while in life insurance below average to negative growth was recorded for individual products.
Non-life insurance in Europe suffered from "lack of demand arising from the poor climate and price competition due to increasing deregulation in the European Union", the report said.
Real drops in premium income were recorded in 7 countries, with the UK holding the negative record with -5.5 per cent because of heavily falling prices following years of good results.
"Growth in life business has also fallen in Europe. This might be an indication of the increasing significance of private pension schemes in economically difficult times," the report said.
Eastern Europe also suffered negative development in 1995, due primarily to trends in the Russian market.
"The virtual tripling of nominal premium income was insufficient to keep pace with hyperinflation," Swiss Re said.
But Asia had the most dynamic markets, bolstered by a powerful upturn in the region's economy.

"South East Asia has once again revealed itself as a growth region par excellence: growth rates in most countries achieved double figures in non life insurance (13.3 per cent) and in life insurance (17.5 per cent)," the report said.
In addition Japan recovered from the weak growth of the previous year to 'normal' growth rates in 1995.

"The most important reason for this may include the attractiveness of savings-linked products. The lines occupational injury and liability recorded the greatest growth; the latter due to poor product liability legislation." the report said.
The Japanese also spent most on insurance, spending $5,088 per inhabitant. The Swiss were in second place with $4,507.
